hints.content: Start by understanding how to rotate a matrix 90 degrees clockwise. For a given element at position (i, j) in an n x n matrix, its new position after rotation will be (j, n-1-i).
Before diving into rotations, check if the dimensions of both matrices are the same. They must be n x n, as specified in the problem statement.
Consider implementing a function that rotates the matrix. You can create a new matrix for the rotated version or modify the original one in place.
Think about how many times you need to rotate the matrix to check all possible orientations. You will need to check the original matrix and its three rotated forms.
After each rotation, compare the current state of the matrix with the target matrix. If they match at any point, you can return true immediately.
Remember to reset the matrix back to its original state after each rotation if you are modifying it in place. This will allow you to check all four orientations.
Consider edge cases where n is 1. In this case, the matrix is just a single element, and you should directly compare the two matrices.
When comparing the matrices, ensure you are checking each element correctly. A simple loop can help you verify if all corresponding elements are equal.
If you find that none of the rotations match the target matrix, make sure to return false at the end of your function.
To summarize your approach: Rotate the matrix up to three times, checking for equality with the target each time. If any match is found, return true; otherwise, return false.

questionNotes: Elements of matrices are binary (0 or 1).
